dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LETITIA DAVIS, 70's, seated at a piano. The score in fron her is THE BRINDISI from LA TRAVIATA, which she is checki She starts to play. FELICITY LIDDLE, 70’s, page turner, i standing nearby. Reveal BOBBY SWANSON, 70’s, conductor, gesturing and whispering musical terms. All we may hear i

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (whispering) .-..allegretto - She starts again. MUSIC continues throughout credits - INT. ANNE LANGLEY’S ROOM - EARLY MORNING A FINGER stirs gargle into a glass of water. The glass is then raised to the mouth of ANNE LANGLEY, 70, soprano. Sh takes a mouthful and gargles. While vocalising, the piano kicks into an ORCHESTRATION of the Brindisi, which continues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CARIBBEAN NURSE'S HANDS (DWAYNE, 20's/30’s) bandaging a female leg, (OCTAVIA, 70's, CHORUS). She sits ina wheelchair, holding the score, mouthing the words in Italian. MUSIC continues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CECILY (CISSY) ROBSON, 70, contralto, bosomy and bountiful, walking the width of the swimming pool rotating her arms. SHERYL, 30's, nurse, standing nearby. CISSY has a CD player above water, corded around her neck, while listening to the Brindisi with earphones on, moving her lips. As she emerges from the pool, SHERYL helps her don a bathrobe. MUSIC continues - INT. FITNESS ROOM —- EARLY MORNING WILFRED (WILF) BOND, 70, baritone, and a few residents, a doing yoga. WILF mouths the score he’s holding, while bei stretched by a FEMALE NURSE, TRACY, 30’s, all the while appreciating her form. MUSIC continues - INT. LEO’S ROOM—- EARLY MORNING A MALE HAND (LEO'S, 70’s) draws a bow across a single str of a cello. The string is tightened. The bow is drawn aga Better. MUSIC continues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CEDRIC LIVINGSTONE, 70's, former counter-tenor, opera director and self-proclaimed critic, applying rouge to hi cheeks, completing his otherwise light street make-up. He powders, while checking the score next to him. He checks time, 7.40 am, rises in his dressing gown, crosses to his closet and selects a caftan from his wall-to-wall collect MUSIC continues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGINALD (REGGIE) PAGET, 70's, tenor, trim, fit, half-moo glasses on the end of his nose, holds the score, vocalisi while standing in front of a mirror adjusting his cravat. MUSIC continues - INT. OLLY FISHER’S ROOM - EARLY MORNING OLLY FISHER, 70's, clarinettist. He tightens a reed onto mouthpiece, practices a phrase, grimaces. OLLY stops mid- phrase. ORCHESTRATION halts. Silence. He inhales and exha with great concentration. Overlap NOBBY chatter -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOBBY, gardener, 50ish, drinks coffee and talks to SIMON, 20, while pushing a wheelbarrow filled with weeds alongside BEECHAM HOUSE. We might pick up a word or two of what he’s saying. SIMON follows his directions. NOBBY continues to chatter as he points to a brick or stone. SIMON picks it up and brings it to him. NOBBY practices a curl, puts it in the wheelbarrow. He continues to walk next to the house, a handsome mansion. Mysterious and inviting. NOBBY hears LETITIA in the COMMON ROOM, practicing the Brindisi. He looks in, sees vaguely and slightly distorted, people milling about, finding seats, faint chatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE 30 or so ELDERLY OPERA SINGERS of Beecham House taking their seats, including OCTAVIA, in a wheelchair, aided by SHERYL. Some hold scores. Among them REGGIE, CISSY, WILF, GEORGE and HARRY. Some musicians carry their instruments - TONY ROSE, 70’s trumpet and DAVE TRUBECK, 70's pianist, DAPHNE MORGAN, 60's, harpist, LEO CASSEL, cellist, and CEDRIC. DR. LUCY COGAN, 30's, attractive, sits on the side, with ANNE LANGLEY. CEDRIC, seated on a throne-like chair, nods to BOBBY. All on BOBBY. He taps a pencil, raises it, nods to LETITIA. FELICITY, beside her, nervous, as she prepares to turn t pages. LETITIA plays the introduction to the Brindisi. BOBBY cue the chorus. No-one sings. Some RESIDENTS are amused, othe confused. BOBBY whispers to LETITIA. Watching, eyes narrowed, CEDRIC, not happy. BOBBY again cues the residents and they begin to sing. They give it their all. During this, FELICITY fumbles turning a page. LETITIA, irritated, nods repeatedly. FELICITY recovers. At the end, BOBBY finishes with a flourish, then turns to CEDRIC. All look at him expectantly. He keeps them waiting, then:

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Nowhere near to where you should be, Bobby. BOBBY nods, continues.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks to WILF in the chorus ) Wilf, I couldn’t work out what you were doing, you were much too fast and we had awful ensemble problems there. Can we hear it from Bar 42? LETITIA and FELICITY, flustered, look for it in the score BOBBY alert, cues them.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (taking the mickey, sings a tad and stops) It’s too fast Bobby. Sorry Cedric. (starts again, stops) Too slow Bobby. Sorry Cedric. (starts again, stops) Now it’s too fast Bobby. Sorry Cedric. Some CHORUS MEMBERS giggle.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Silenzio. You never followed the conductor, did you? You always thought you were superior.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I am. NIGEL, 70's, BARITONE, sings the phrase that CEDRIC requested. WILF stares him down as CEDRIC smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Nigel. Lotte, in bars 17, 18, 19, you were flat.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think I was. I think the piano needs tuning.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (looks at ANNE LANGLEY) Anne, would you mind singing it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: (as she’s getting up) I don’t do chorus, Cedric. (walking toward the door) I’m going to have my breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (watches her go, turns to

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Cissy, you're still not certain of the words. We only have a month and a half -

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (mischievously) That’s six weeks, isn’t it, Reggie?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (CEDRIC gives them a hard look) Yes, six weeks, three days -

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: - one hour -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Give or take a minute -

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: And seconds out! CISSY tries to untangle her earphones.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (enunciates each word) Cissy - please - pay - attention.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Of course you are. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will all members of the Gala Committee - and remember that includes you, Cissy - please note that there’s an emergency meeting at twelve noon sharp! I don’t use the adjective, “emergency,” lightly. I will start as the hour strikes. He totters out on his ivory cane motioning to BOBBY to follow him. Much chatter.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to remind me, Reggie-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’ll set the alarm. As REGGIE sets his watch, OCTAVIA starts to sing. Her voi is remarkably strong but at one point, she forgets the words, and substitutes “Dee-dee-dee-dee.” She stops, embarrassed. The other singers remain respectful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The residents are eating their breakfasts. Some are being served coffee. DWAYNE doles out pills to various RESIDENT SHERYL, sits next to OCTAVIA. Two Polish waitresses, MART and EVA, chat in Polish to each other as they clear. They start to clear the plate of DAPHNE MORGAN who is finishin her porridge. At her table are TONY ROSE and DAVE.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE
dialogues.text: Wait, wait! (takes another two mouthfuls then pushes the bowl towards them) Thank you. EVA and MARTA, unphased, continue chatting in Polish and on to other tables, passing ANNE LANGLEY and then GEORGE, Chorus. GEORGE is observing an argument going on at a tab next to a window where REGGIE and CISSY are sitting, her earphones by her side. At the only other table by the win sits CEDRIC, LETITIA, and BOBBY. CISSY glances out the window. It’s the chorus vs. the soloists. HARRY is standing between REGGIE and an empty chair (WILF’S). HARRY makes a few attempts to move the chair to seat himself, but REGGIE holds firmly with one hand and one leg, as he continues to do The Telegraph crossword. The following argument should be overlapped -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (from the other table) You can’t save seats, Reg! REGGIE ignores GEORGE, holding fast to the chair with on and one hand while he continues to do the crossword.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (trying to pull the seat) You soloists come in and just sing a few arias. We sing the entire bloody opera.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (pulls back) You may be on stage the entire time, but you're not actually singing, you're just standing in the back. HARRY begins to argue back and REGGIE overrides him. REGGIE (CONT’D) (indicates people at his table) Why now, Harry? We’ve been sitting at this table for as long as I’ve been here. WILF has entered the dining room, supported by his cane, waving to others as he goes toward his table.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Exactly my point! If this place shuts down in six months, which it bloody well could - (he looks at others in the room) I want to be able to look back and remember I had a fucking window seat! As WILF reaches the table, a few cheers from GEORGE and other chorus residents seated at their tables.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He moves the empty chair over and sits in it with difficu holding his cane. HARRY goes back to his table, sits, sta to take his pills.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: I could have had a window seat, but I much prefer to sit by myself. CISSY, a bit unnerved, puts her earphones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can’t deny it, Wilf, soloists would be nothing without us.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: If I hear that again, Harry, I may stick a fork up your jacksy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sitting next to

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: He’s right, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Anybody got a fork?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know he is-

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Make that two forks. ANGELIQUE, 20, French, has brought WILF a full English breakfast. He is getting his usual special treatment from ANGELIQUE as other plates are getting cleared.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Merci, Angelique. Have you done something new to your hair?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: No. It’s the same. I just put fringe in front.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I love your fringe in front. REGGIE looks up from his paper.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Extra slice fried bread this morning and your favourite- (places jam on his tray) - apricot Jam. REGGIE lowers his paper and looks steelily at ANGELIQUE.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dr. Cogan she say too much of the sugar is bad for you, but I know you like very much. Same for Madame Langley. With a wink, she nods in the direction of ANNE LANGLEY, who sits at a nearby table eating delicately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’re an angel, Angelique. C’est magnifique. Vous fancy a rumpy- pumpy cette soiree, Angelique?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Qu’est que c’est “rumpy pumpy”?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Angelique, are we getting married or not? I need your answer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: (used to it) Bon appetit! She goes. REGGIE lowers his paper, stares at her. CISSY looks out of the window. CEDRIC, at the next table, leans over and taps her. She removes her earphones and lo at CEDRIC.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Cissy, remember, the emergency meeting is at twelve noon. Precisely. CISSY nods, turns back, puts earphones on.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (turns to CEDRIC) Cedric, it’s breakfast time. CEDRIC motions towards CISSY’s back. He rotates his finge indicating CISSY is unbalanced.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Cedric! Chill! Hullo or bonjour, look — He points to the window. DR. COGAN is speaking urgently to TADEK, as they walk past the window. TADEK carries a window squeegee and a cloth. WILF watches them. EXT. DRIVE, BEECHAM HOUSE - WILF’S POV - DAY A people carrier is in the driveway. On the side of the vehicle:

dialogues.speaker: HOME FOR RETIRED MUSICIANS
dialogues.text: DR. COGAN leaves. TADEK cleans the windows. He gets in th van and starts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (to REGGIE) Didn’t you say today’s the day?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: What’s today?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (to CISSY) Tadek setting off to fetch the new arrival.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: At least now we’1ll know who it is.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (excited) What? What? Is there to be a new arrival?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Cissy, we've been talking about it for days.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Have I? Have we? Then who is it? How do you know it’s today?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They’d only send the van for a star.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: They sent a private car with a chauffeur for me.  10

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: When I came I had to pay for my own taxi.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s the replacement for poor old Laurence Timms. Dear oh dear, I do miss him. (they eat) But I’1l tell you this, I never knew a man to fart like Laurence.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Wilf, please. Concerned that it will offend CISSY, REGGIE looks at her. But to his dismay, CISSY is smiling, enjoying WILF’S story.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: That man could fart at will -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Please, I’m eating my breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I’m not making this up Reg. - he would get down on the floor on all fours, go into a meditative state, until his entire body relaxed. At which point he could actually inhale and exhale through his anal canal-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Willllf!! CISSY sees NOBBY in the garden. WILF notices CISSY watchi NOBBY.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: - and when he exhaled, it came out as a crepitation. That’s what he called it. What a gentleman! His record was one hundred and thirty- seven crepitations in a row.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (resigned) I give up.  11

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (to CISSY, teasing) Cissy, will I do instead of Nobby for a quick one in the long grass? CISSY, continuing to listen to her CD, turns back to her breakfast but her napkin falls from her lap. WILF is about to retrieve it but doesn't, so that CISSY has to lean down, revealing her ample cleavage. WILF observes CISSY'S bosom while putting apricot jam on his toast. WILF (CONT’D) May I tell you, Cissy, in all honesty, that you still have the most beautiful tits I’ve ever seen? CISSY finds her napkin, sits up, triumphant, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Takes a bite of his toast.) In fact, your whole body causes me to pulsate with lust. She smiles, blithely, as REGGIE glares at WILF'S toast. WILF (CONT’D) (to REGGIE) Pass the apricot jam, old son- REGGIE controls his irritation. CISSY reaches across and passes the jam to WILF and returns to her CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast over, the residents continue to make their way slowly out of the dining room. The maids continue to clea while NIGEL, on his way out, passes WILF and REGGIE who a getting up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: NIGEL
dialogues.text: For the record Wilf, Cedric was right, you were too slow.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Stick it where the sun don’t shine, Nigel. LETITIA and FELICITY, the pianists, appear at REGGIE’s an WILF’s side. The following is overlapped -

dialogues.speaker: LETITIA
dialogues.text: Do any of you yet know what you propose to do for the gala?  12

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I was thinking of giving my Figaro.

dialogues.speaker: FELICITY
dialogues.text: You must let me know in plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: LETITIA
dialogues.text: Felicity dear, I’m the pianist. I’m the one who plays the score. You're the one who turns the pages. FELICITY and LETITIA walk away.

dialogues.speaker: FELICITY
dialogues.text: I’m still a professional and I can’t bear it when you’re annoyed with me. CISSY stops at LOTTE’S table.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you were out of tune at all.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Anne, what are you going to do for the gala?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: What? She continues to eat.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What are you going to do for the gala? She spontaneously begins to sing an aria from TOSCA - Vissi D'Arte.  13

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to REGGIE, sotto voce) Sorry I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beecham House van is parked in front of one of the elegant houses on the street. Bottles of milk are being delivered to the house next door. Above, JEAN HORTON, at her flat window, is watching. TADEK and the BUILDING ATTENDANT emerge carrying suitcases and load them into the van. The ATTENDANT stays with the van as TADEK goes back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. JEAN HORTON’S FLAT - DAY WIDE SHOT on her back, silhouetted, revealing again JEAN HORTON, mid 70s, air of a grande dame, standing alone nea a window in her living room, empty of furniture, dust mar where pictures once hung. There are sealed trunks and suitcases on the ground with decals of different countrie She is smartly dressed but in somewhat dated clothing. TADEK comes in to collect more suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Be careful with that one, it’s fragile.

dialogues.speaker: TADEK
dialogues.text: I come back for trunk. And for you. TADEK leaves. JEAN continues to stare out the window.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. PEOPLE CARRIER, COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: The people carrier making its way along the country road. TADEK at the wheel. JEAN in a rear seat, lost in forlorn thought. She has been writing on the back of a newspaper. She mouths words softly.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: - I apologise - be kind to me - we were different then - no, no - we were - I can't do this -  14

dialogues.speaker: TADEK
dialogues.text: (glancing in the rear mirror) Madam, you say to me something? JEAN is suddenly overcome with alarm:

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Stop! Turn round. Go back -

dialogues.speaker: TADEK
dialogues.text: What? What? You wanna go back? No, no, I must call Dr. Cogan -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (confused, in a state) Don’t be such a damn fool, drive on!

dialogues.speaker: TADEK
dialogues.text: Madam, what you want? Stop, go, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF, on the chair lift, holding a remote control, descends slowly while humming. He sees a dazzling bunch of garden flowers being arranged in a vase by DR. COGAN. DAPHNE is helping.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Never seen you arrange flowers before, Dr. Cogan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Really Wilf, haven’t you noticed that we’ve had to cut down on staff in the last few months?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Is it for a new arrival? (No answer, with his remote, he pauses the chair lift) Is that a new skirt? I haven't seen it before. It really clings to you beautifully. It actually accentuates your already beautiful legs. Don’t you agree, Daphne? DAPHNE, embarrassed, demurs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (amused) You're overstepping the line, Wilf.  15

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I know. WILF dismounts the chair lift.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Go for your walk, Wilfred.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I'd love it if you could join me, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Go for your walk.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: passing her) I must tell you Lucy, it’s hard to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (continues arranging flowers) Do your best.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: May I? WILF picks a flower and tries to put it in his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t see it without my glasses. Would you be so kind? WILF bends while DR. COGAN goes to fit the flower in his Their faces close. He grins at her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have a lapel, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Go for your walk, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other residents and their visitors also taking the air, greeting each other. WILF waves. Some wave back. From a nearby window, the muffled, intermittent sound of “Underneath the Arches” accompanied by piano and trumpet. Four Gilbert and Sullivan singers are playing croquet.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: A pound says I'll kick your arse, Nigel.

dialogues.speaker: NIGEL
dialogues.text: The way you play, I’m sure you will.  16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF continues to stroll. Faintly we hear the sound of a clarinet coming from the SUMMERHOUSE. Sitting inside, OLLY FISHER playing “Who is Sylvia.” WILF pauses, waves to OLLY. OLLY then takes a deep breath and another. He takes a pil from his pill box and puts it under his tongue. WILF obse closely. When his breathing is restored, WILF and OLLY exchange a thumbs up. EXT. FOUNTAIN GARDEN —- DAY NOBBY chatters while overseeing SIMON digging over a bed. WILF strolls toward them from behind.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (calling to him) Morning, Nobby.

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: (calling back) Morning, Mr. Bond.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Simon, wassup?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: All good, mate.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a scorcher.

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: Global warming.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Or just an English summer, one of the two. By the way, when you have a chance I could use another of the “usual.” NOBBY refuses money that WILF offers him.

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: No problem. I still have change from the last time. I’11 put it in the “usual” place. NOBBY nods his head to a place off the premises.  17

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (continues to walk) And watch out, Nobby, Cissy Robson's been looking for you all morning. Can't think why, I'm so much more attractive. WILF walks on.

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: (calls out) Says you. (beat, shouts after WILF) How’s the leg?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the terrace, tables and chairs under parasols. Residents reading, TONY and DAVE are playing a game of draughts. REGGIE sits at a table in a shaded corner, writing, preparing his lecture - A BIOGRAPHY OF VERDI and The Telegraph are on the table next to him. CISSY, seated next to REGGIE, listens to her CD while watching TWO LITTLE GIRLS (one of them is ESME) and a BOY playing on the grass. LETITIA, sitting on the other side of the terrace, with her DAUGHTER, chat while watching their kids. WILF approaches, goes to sit next to REGGIE and CISSY. REGGIE glances up and continues writing.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (as he sits) I read somewhere that the average man thinks about sex every seven seconds.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (writing) And do you?  18

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (gazing at CISSY as she sits) I wish it was only every seven seconds.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You need to see a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Male or female? REGGIE continues to write.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (picking up a newspaper on the table, pulls his glasses on, looks at the crossword puzzle) You left a word out. (states the clue - and he gets it, pauses, he studies CISSY, takes his glasses off) When I first saw her, God knows how long ago, I thought she was the most beautiful, sexiest thing I'd ever clapped eyes on. The alarm on REGGIE’S wristwatch sounds. He is about to t CISSY on the arm but WILF stops him with a look.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cissy, let Reg and me have our way with you now. Go on, bea sport, on the lawn, legs apart, bloomers abandoned. I'll remove my truss. (taps her on the arm with his cane, she removes her headset and looks at WILF) How about it?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Ready. WILF loves it. REGGIE is forced to smile.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Nothing -  19

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Why did you interrupt me? Can’t you see I’m listening to us?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Rigoletto. The quartet. We are so lovely -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Were. (taps his watch) Cissy, the gala committee.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh yes, yes - She rises, in a flurry, starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (to WILF) Royal Opera House, Nineteen- Sixty - whatever it was, Covent Garden. Do you remember, Wilf?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s the last time the four of us sang it. We had done it, what, fifty times before that? CISSY comes darting back for her bag.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: And thank you Reggie. I’m so relieved you’re safely back from Karachi. She starts to hurry away, but momentarily can’t remember which way to go. Clutching her bag, leaving the CD cover the table, but it falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Why Karachi?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Her father was Indian army.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes, so he was. Do you think she's getting worse?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes.  20 WILF bends down to pick up the CD cover, but ends up sitting on the ground. He looks at the CD cover. REGGIE (CONT’D) (still reading and making notes) I’m glad they’ve reissued it. We might get royalties. WILF tries vainly to get up.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I wish they’d reissue us instead. REGGIE helps him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They might have put our photographs on the cover instead of just our names. WILF studies the CD cover. In bold letters against an appropriate background: CLASSIC RECORDINGS - Jean HORTON sings GILDA with Reginald PAGET, Cecily ROBSON, Wilfred BOND in RIGOLETTO

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dizzy heights, those days. (sits) ‘Jean Horton sings Gilda.’ I should have had top billing. Name part, after all. (looks off) I remember the production, the recording sessions, everything, as if it were yesterday yet I can't remember what we had for breakfast this morning-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) - fucking apricot jam, that’s what you had.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (looks at CD again) Everyone said the quartet had never been better sung. My picture in the Daily Mail with the caption: “Wilfred Bond - A New Star?” Question mark. I was famous for a day. Still, I made a living and that’s all I ever wanted. I’m not like you, Reg. You’re an artist, I’m an artisan —  21

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Have you listened to it?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: No. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: No, no way, Wilf. No way.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Of course. Clumsy of me. These two old friends share a moment. REGGIE writes again CISSY returns, panicked.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Have you seen my CD case? WILF hands it to her. She rushes away as SIMON walks by.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (to SIMON - a rap line from Tinie Tempah’s "Pass Out”) “I'm born famous I’m sorta’ known”

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: “If your son doesn’t”

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: “I bet your daughter knows” WILF and SIMON put their fists in the air. REGGIE makes a face. WILF (CONT’D) Reg, you might as well get used to it. Rap is here to stay.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Why? Rap is not music.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It is to them.  22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY hurries through the Music Room. The Gilbert and Sullivan troop are rehearsing “Flowers that Bloom in the Spring.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated around a table are BOBBY, ANNE LANGLEY, LETITIA an DAPHNE, who takes the minutes. CEDRIC, in a new caftan, i standing and in full flight, waving The Times under BOBBY nose pointing at an interview with a photo of FRANK WHITE CISSY opens the door quietly and comes in.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (to the table) ..-When this came out last week we were assured of our much needed sell out concert and increased donations. Now it’s a bloody disaster. If we can’t make the gala into the hottest ticket in town, this house could collapse about our ears. We could lose it. None of us wants to be turfed out into the street with nowhere to go. (looks up, sees CISSY)

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (at the door) I certainly don’t want to be turfed out.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Apologies. (nothing from the others; they stare at her) What? What? I apologise for being late, I’m sorry, I -

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (throws the paper down on the table) Close the door. Frank White has pulled out. He doesn’t feel up for the Gala.

dialogues.speaker: LETITIA
dialogues.text: He’s not well.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: Obviously.  23

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (at the closed door) And one of our gala highlights. Oh dear! Frank White, such a lovely man.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (tapping the table sharply) This is a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Who was it who said, 'Old age is not for sissies'?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Next item!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I always remember that because of my name, you see, Cissy, sissies -

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (to CISSY) Cissy! If you want to speak, raise your hand! (picks up a financial paper, tosses it to

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: As of today, pledges from our benefactors have fallen by 60%. The givers aren’t giving. We have to find a replacement for Frank, urgently. CISSY raises her hand. From the next room we faintly hear “Flowers that bloom in the spring, tra-la” etc.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Bette Davis! She was the one who said old age is not- CEDRIC moves toward CISSY. She stops talking, frightened. CEDRIC walks right past her - goes to the door, opens it, walks out. CEDRIC’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: SILENZIO
dialogues.text: (singing continues) Shut it! (they stop mid way through Tra-La-La) You will choose a different song immediately. I will have no Tra-La- La at MY gala!  24 CEDRIC storms back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What about Reggie? La Donna é Mobile?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Good. Cissy ask him.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Reggie is funny about La Donna é Mobile. I don’t think he will.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Your job is to ask him!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Look! They all turn to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As DR. COGAN and SIMON wait, the people carrier comes to a halt at the entrance. DR. COGAN helping JEAN to alight. TADEK and SIMON, unload her trunk and many suitcases. In the driveway, a lorry is picking up laundry in sacks. JEAN sees them being loaded. CISSY’S VOICE (barely audible) Heavens above -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. COGAN escorts JEAN through the front door. They start to walk through the empty large room. She is unhappy, embattled. JEAN looks up at A LARGE PAINTING of Sir Thomas Beecham.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: That's Sir Thomas Beecham. One of Britain’s great conductors. The house is named after him.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I know who Sir Thomas Beecham was, thank you. He inherited a fortune. His grandfather made laxatives -so I’m sure naming this nursing home after him is frighteningly apt.  25

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (patiently) It is not a nursing home. It is an exclusive, private retirement home. DR. COGAN opens the second door to the MAIN HALL and JEAN limps through it. They pause at the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are to welcome you. I'll have them sent up to your room later. We're very honoured to have you. You have a lovely room. Our largest. In what we call the “BY Wing -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The “B” Wing? Sounds like prison.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (smiles uncertainly) The service lift is being repaired - (indicates with her hand) - but you can take the chair lift, it’ll be easier for you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (looks at the chair lift at the bottom of the stairs) Take the chair lift? What do I do when I get to the top? Ski down? JEAN follows the rail from the bottom stair to the top. From behind, someone begins to clap. Then more join in. JEAN turns and looks up. She sees RESIDENTS applauding he from the MAIN HALL LANDING. JEAN is at first taken aback but then visibly glows, takes a step into the MAIN HALL, smiles and nods graciously.

dialogues.speaker: OCTAVIA
dialogues.text: Brava!

dialogues.speaker: OTHER VOICES
dialogues.text: (joining in) Brava! Brava!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on a sharp crack, a ball goes through a hoop. Not an easy shot. WILF, mallet in one hand, walking stick in the other, watches. Their banter is habitual:  26

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (lining up his next shot, turns to WILF) What about (names a part in an opera)? Just in time, REGGIE sees WILF’S foot move his own ball towards the hoop for an easier shot. REGGIE (CONT’D) (off-hand, not taking his eye off his ball) You just moved your ball.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Me? Unthinkable -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I saw you -—

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Never-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I clearly just saw you move it - WILF has been watching an attractive female visitor walki by with her husband.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (eyes following the woman) Balls!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Precisely. Wilf, she’s married.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Precisely. (he quotes a phrase from an Opera in Italian) They play on and are enthusiastic about the prospect of performing.  He plays. through. 27

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (lining up his shot) We could always do “The Barber,” you, Cissy, and I, for the Gala. That would draw the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Yes, but what I would love to sing again is Macbeth! It’s been years, and I miss it.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (aiming) I always wanted to sing Wagner. Tristan. Just once. But it never came my way. Too many parts, too little time. (looks at WILF) Stand back. You’re obscuring my line.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: You won’t get it through, not from there-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (melodramatic) Oh yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (melodramatic) Oh no you won't. The ball hits the hoop but doesn’t go

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (walks to a nearby tree) Told you.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You were in the way.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Was not -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Were!

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (starts to unzip) Was not!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (looks at WILF behind the tree) What are you doing now?  28

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What does it look like I’m doing now? (trying to urinate) Wagner?!! Only bloody foreigners sing Wagner. We're best at the British composers. Rossini, Donizetti, Verdi - (REGGIE smiles; WILF looks down) C'mon! C’mon! CISSY’S VOICE Reggie! Wilf! They turn to see CISSY rushing towards them out of breath and over-excited.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I know who it is, I saw her, I saw her, George was right, it’s a star, but you’1ll never, never, never guess who, never -

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (zipping up) Then tell us, we don’t want to be kept in suspense for eternity-

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You won't believe this. Still large as life and twice as terrifying. (suddenly still) Oh God! It’s gone! Damnation, what’s her name, begins with G. Soprano, famous -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Famous soprano beginning with G. Mary Garden -

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Rita Gorr -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Galli-Curci -

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Cissy, think. She thinks, brow furrowed.  29

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Gilda! Our Gilda!

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Oh! G, Gilda, yes, I see, our “Gilda,” Rigoletto. You mean Jean Horton-

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Yes! How clever of you! Yes, Jean Horton.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Jean Horton? Here? (he and CISSY look at

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You all right, old son? REGGIE is frozen. No response.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: If it’s any consolation, Reg, she’s aged terribly. She looks a hundred- Brief, tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Steady, Reg, steady, NSP, NSP - REGGIE walks away.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It'll be all right, old son, trust me — REGGIE throws down his mallet and marches off towards the house. WILF and CISSY watch him, deeply concerned. INT. DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - DAY DR. COGAN, standing beside a table getting coffee. REGGIE is standing.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (furious) ...that’s why you kept it such a secret. You didn’t want me to know. It’s intolerable. I should have been consulted, Dr. Cogan. I should have been warned.  30

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Jean Horton was such a big star. She didn’t want media attention. Nor did we -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She didn’t want? Always, always, always what she wants - nothing changes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (gently) It had nothing to do with you, Reginald. It was simply at her request.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She did know that I live here?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She knew. (Beat) It's been so calm here. So agreeable. (DR. COGAN listens sympathetically as REGGIE rails on) Do you know what I wanted? I wanted a dignified senility. I scrimped and saved - repaired my own clothes, had only one glass of red wine a day. One! My only indulgence was to buy from time to time my favourite cologne. And why? So that I could afford without charity a decent room of my own in this house. And now she’s here. (moving toward the door) I shall have to find somewhere else to live.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Reginald, I’m sure she -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You don’t know her! REGGIE opens the door to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Aren’t you giving a talk to the school children tomorrow?  31

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (resigned, as he’s leaving) Dear God -

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Your talks are so valuable, Reggie. These children have never been to an opera -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a television - OTELLO. Three or four RESIDENTS, including NORMA, are watching, among them, ANNE LANGLEY.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: (gesturing to TV) Why can’t we find Otello’s like that today - they don’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Desdemona sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: That’s such an easy part. They continue their critique of the performances. A burst of laughter from the other side of the room as WI slaps down a card theatrically.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Canasta! I win!

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN PLAYER
dialogues.text: You cheated! Reveal at a corner of the room, WILF sits with REGINA, violin, LOTTE and MARION. DR. COGAN enters the room and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Wilf, have you seen Reginald?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: He turned in early. But he’s fine. Tough as a monkey’s tit, is Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (turns toward the terrace) Who’s smoking?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I suspect it’s George and Harry.  32 The French doors are open, through which the backs of GEO and HARRY can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know how many times I’ve told them, smoking kills!

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: For god’s sake, doc, leave ‘em be. George is seventy-six and Harry's nearly eighty. What the hell’s it matter?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (smiles ) You're a bad influence, Wilfred. DR. COGAN shakes her head, turns and walks away as WILF watches her.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Give us a wiggle- (DR. COGAN continues walking) Do that again.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t give you the first one.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: If I live another five years, I'll have her. I just need time.  33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN, with difficulty, puts a record player next to the flowers on a table. She takes the cord in hand, looking f an outlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim light. DR. COGAN comes along the corridor, sees a light under a door, knocks gently and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN is kneeling, trying to fit the plug of the record player into a socket on the skirting board. She puts on h glasses. In the suitcase beside her, a pile of LPs - we barely make out the titles - JEAN HORTON’S GREATEST ARIAS and THE BEST OF JEAN HORTON, others. She hears the knock, hurriedly closes the suitcase, takes off her glasses, tries to rise, but can’t. She winces in pain as DR COGAN looks in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (a little alarmed, hesitant to help) Are you all right? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a withering stare from JEAN; gently) Isn't this room lovely?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The bed takes up half the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: You've had a long day. You might want to retire early.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I have not yet entered second childhood so please don’t talk to me as though I have. Just leave me be. And I will take my meals in my room. A brief pause.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: We don’t usually serve the residents in their rooms.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You do, I presume, when the resident is not feeling well. I’m not feeling well. DR COGAN hesitates, uncertain as whether or not to offer JEAN a helping hand. She decides against it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I hope you feel better soon. DR. COGAN turns and walks out. JEAN struggles to get up and finally sits by the window, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. COGAN comes to a door. No light showing. On the door, a small brass plaque of the type used on dressing room doors with the name:

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD PAGET
dialogues.text: She wants to knock but hesitates, decides against it and continues on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE, a silhouette, stands on the terrace of his room, gazing at a lighted window in the “B” Wing. He can just m out JEAN seated in a chair.  From REGGIE, we move on to LEO in his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gilbert and Sullivan troop You, Sir, We Much Regret” with One of the four turns the page FELICITY is irritated. Through 35 playing “The Swan” on his cello are rehearsing “So Please FELICITY at the piano. of the score too soon. the window we see NOBBY deadheading roses while SIMON rakes. EXT./INT. WILF’S WINDOW & ROOM — MORNING The music continues over the following scenes. Above the COMMON ROOM, where the four Gilbert and Sullivan singers are rehearsing, the window is flung open and WILF stands greeting the morning air. He goes from breathing deeply to vocalising. CISSY’S VOICE Yoo-hoo! He sees CISSY leaning out her window. He follows her gaze down towards NOBBY and SIMON. NOBBY looks up to see CISSY at him, leaning forward, allowing her window, gazing down at her cleavage to show. She waves alluringly just as WILF'S VOICE, doing scales, comp with the Gilbert and Sullivan singers. NOBBY takes a break from the roses. He removes his shirt and wipes his forehead as he flexes, exciting CISSY.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. JEAN'S ROOM —- MORNING JEAN, asleep in the chair by the window, an LP jacket sitting in her lap. She is woken with a start by the cacophony of singing and vocalising. Wearily, she raises her eyes to heaven. EXT. WILF’S WINDOW Looking down, WILF sees CISSY, a robe over her bathing suit, being coquettish with NOBBY and SIMON on her way to the swimming pool building.  36

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Those roses are so beautiful. What are they called, Nobby?

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: They're Elizabeth of Glamis, Miss Robson, named after the late Queen Mother. And those are Iceberg.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Named after Jean Horton, I suppose. She knows she’s made a joke. She puts a finger to her lip and runs off. NOBBY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (calling to NOBBY) Nobby - 1. Wilf - Nil!

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM, BREAKFAST
dialogues.text: Close on Newspapers being dropped on tables or chairs as RESIDENTS eat. They vary, depending on the preference of reader. WILF and LEO at their table. The seat next to WIL (REGGIE'S) is empty. WILF and SIMON exchange nods as SIMO drops The Telegraph on the seat. His Full English breakfa hardly touched. WILF takes the paper and finds the sports page.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (with HARRY, at their table) Is Reggie coming or not? This really is very unfair.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s all yours, boys - As WILF leaves, GEORGE immediately starts to move their plates as CEDRIC smirks at his table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF taps lightly on REGGIE'S door. No answer. He cracks the door open, looks and walks in. He sees no one there. WILF leaves and closes the door. Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF descends the staircase. He enters the COMMON ROOM wh DAVE is playing BACH’S FUGUE IN D MINOR on the piano. WIL walks to the FITNESS ROOM, opens the door, CEDRIC is havi his nails done.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Excuse me, this room is occupied!

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (as he closes the door) Don’t do your toes the same color, Cedric, it’s considered gauche. WILF (CONT’D) Good Morning, Dr. C. Have you seen Reggie?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he asked if he could use the computer. He’s in my office. INT. ENTRANCE HALL - OUTSIDE DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - MORNING WILF knocks and opens the door. He sees REGGIE inside at the computer. INT. DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Reggie. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t wish to be disturbed. I’m working.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Can I get you a cup of cof--

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m preparing my talk. Please close the door when you leave. WILF looks at REGGIE then walks out, closing the door. ON THE COMPUTER SCREEN: Rap information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a table, a tray with half a glass of juice. JEAN is holding a cup of coffee while laying out her clothes for the day. Most of the suitcases remain unopened.  38 Disconcerted, she drops a garment back into an opened portmanteau. JEAN moves to the dressing-table, sits, gazi at herself in the mirror. She holds up different pieces o jewelry. A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Who? CISSY’S VOICE A friend.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Come. CISSY enters. JEAN stares at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (as to a child) It’s me, Jean. Cissy. Cicely Robson.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why does everybody here treat me like a half-wit? (goes back to brushing her hair; off-hand) I know who you are. Where's Reggie?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: It's lovely to see you here, Jean. I've been telling everyone, you still look like a young girl -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (checks her profile in the mirror) I don’t feel it. I'm very slow. I'm on a waiting-list for a new hip.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You have such beautiful jewelry. JEAN starts to put a necklace on.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, do let me, Jean. You remember how you used to like me to give your make-up the once over before you went on? (clips the necklace, and picks out a pair of earrings) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll have you looking as you always did, youthful and whining - (corrects herself quickly) Shining. Youthful and shining - In the mirror JEAN watches CISSY.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (a trace of an affectionate smile) You certainly haven't changed. I asked you where Reggie is. JEAN, through the window, sees a COACH pulling up. School children start to get out.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who are those children?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (looking) Oh, Reggie must be giving one of his talks today. (noticing the tray with orange juice) Did they serve you breakfast in your room?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Of course they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY and JEAN walk from JEAN’S ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: ...-what with people being sent away if they're too ill or go completely doolally, of course one gets depressed from time to time - I mean, I’ve woken up with the black dog on my shoulder a couple of times - but it never lasts for long. How could it? You'll see, we all look after each other and that's very cheering - JEAN and CISSY walk on. JEAN and CISSY are near the bottom of the stairs. BOBBY, the background, waits.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...there's so much to enjoy here. People coming and going -  40

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (hissing) Cissy!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (continuing) - new faces, old friends, families with their children, new interests - From behind a door the sound of salsa music.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What's that awful noise?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m in this class. CISSY opens the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERYL, is teaching salsa to a group of residents who try to follow her movements.

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: Cissy! You're missing class, come on in.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (game as ever) Oh, shall we, Jean?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (to herself) This is not a retirement home, this is a madhouse. CISSY goes in and does some steps. JEAN gives her a withering look and starts to walk on. CISSY starts out after her as BOBBY intercepts her, handing her a note.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (hissing) Birthday Benefit Gala. Emergency. Top secret. He scuttles off. CISSY puts on glasses, reads the note as catches up with JEAN.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Didn't that used to be Bobby Swanson?  41

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (puzzled by the note) Yes -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He didn't seem to recognise me. How odd.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: His sight isn't what it was. CISSY and JEAN walk on.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Such an_intense little man. He always looks as though he's SPY. ing for a foreign power. What does the note say?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Birthday Benefit Gala. Emergency. Top Secret.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Birthday benefit gala? Whose birthday? Mine isn't until the 6th of January?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (re-reading the note, puzzled) No, no, not yours, Jean, Giuseppe Verdi's. There's a Benefit Gala. Everyone's expected to perform to save our Beecham House-

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, perform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk toward the SMALL MUSIC ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: We have to do what we do, Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: At our age? Ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Everyone does something.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I won't sing at Verdi's gala or anyone else’s. And that's final.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I was listening to our Rigoletto this morning. We were all so good, especially your Gilda.  42

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (taking the compliment) I never got less than twelve curtain calls. (looking at the note) What’s the emergency?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (shows JEAN the note) I don't know. He's written 'No one'. What can it mean?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Please, I want to find Reggie. They enter the SMALL MUSIC ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: He’s right here. (starts for the door)

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (panics, whispers) No - Wait. Cissy. No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on the faces of the school children. They have bee asked a question by REGGIE, and are shy, or reluctant to answer. They are from a variety of ethnic backgrounds. So surreptitiously fiddle with their mobile phones. REGGIE stands before them. A nearby upright piano against the wall. In the back we see DR. COGAN sitting with OCTAVIA in her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Come on, don’t be shy - Eventually, A GIRL puts her hand up.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL
dialogues.text: Lady Gaga -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Lady Gaga, sounds like someone I know - From the group, A MALE TEENAGER, hip-hop-ish, JOEY, looki at his mobile phone -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what about you?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (puts his phone away, not making eye contact) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lady Gaga is pop, we like hip- hop, period.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Is hip hop like rap?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Kinda man, but it’s different.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (looking at JOEY) Help me out here, tell me what’s rap? At the door, in the SMALL MUSIC ROOM, CISSY starts to ope it. JEAN, consternated, holds her back.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Wait. Don’t. Wait, wait. CISSY has already cracked the door open a bit. Out of sig they listen. JEAN doesn’t know whether to stay or leave.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Show him! SCHOOL CHILDREN start to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL PUPIL
dialogues.text: Spit it!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Drop a verse, man.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (looking off) Raps from the street while you're in class, so all you teachers can kiss my ass - SCHOOL CHILDREN laugh.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Go on! Continue!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Continue what?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What you're feeling. Now, they share a look - his friends push him to stand up

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (busts out) What you wanna know? ‘bout how I grow to be a bad ‘ting? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or the way that my brain sings When I think of my birth What you wanna know? You wanna know hate crime? Or life rhymes? Or the way that the po-po Makes my heart go When their jake tops wail by? (mimes a siren) Ne-nah ne-nah ne-nah (class laughs, JOEY is getting into this) What you wanna know? You wanna know how life down my endz Means we aint no politicians friend We’re the excuse, we're the left-— outs, we're the done What you wanna know? Pause as they eye each other.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What does “po-po” mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Cops.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: And jake tops?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Cops.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: (suddenly free-styles)

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s opera! Originally people just like yourselves went to see Opera. But then the rich came along and made it something that it’s not. So what is it then? Someone said, ‘Opera is when a guy is stabbed in the back and while he’s bleeding, he sings.' (some school children laugh; ) Rap is when a guy gets stabbed in the back and while he’s bleeding, he talks - rhythmically and emotionally, but because rap is spoken the emotion is held in check. It’s on one note. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Why should we listen to some old fart, giving us shit about his art.’ In Opera, however, we sing our feelings to the rise and fall of the music. The song sets our emotions free. OPERA

dialogues.speaker: THE EMOTIONS THAT ALL OF US
dialogues.text: CARRY INSIDE. And...it’s performed by athletes! Oh yes! (he points to three kids) Can you stand up? You three - you’re fit young men. Football players? They nod.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, we have athletes here as well. Let me introduce you to the wonderful Octavia. She’1ll be joining us for this next part. (points to the rappers) You gentlemen, stand up, pick a note, sing it, and hold it for as long as you can and as loudly as you can. Octavia, will do the same. Ready? One..two..three..Go! The three school children and OCTAVIA sing their notes. T peter out at around ten seconds. OCTAVIA keeps going on a When she finally stops -

dialogues.speaker: OCTAVIA
dialogues.text: (smiles) I’m seventy-nine. What’s your excuse? When I was your age, I had the highest recorded C note. THE SCHOOL CHILDREN laugh and applaud.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What you’ve witnessed is the strength and athleticism of an Opera singer. The people who live here have the superhuman effort it takes to deliver the goods, to breathe, yes, to hold a note — (gestures to OCTAVIA) - like the one Octavia just sang - (distracted by the door opening a crack; irritated) Who is that? CISSY widens the door to include her and JEAN. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: It’s us!  46 As some kids turn to the door, REGGIE sees JEAN, bridles, and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: The heroines, sopranos - those are the ladies with the highest voices - they sing a repetitive theme that’s in all opera. Infidelity. Infidelity. Infidelity. As the Duke sings in Rigoletto - REGGIE looks again at the door. It’s empty. He stares at

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (disconcerted) ‘La donna é mobile qual plumo al vento’. Women are as fickle as a feather in the wind.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF is playing draughts with GEORGE, while HARRY watches. WILF sees REGGIE on the lawn walk by.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Reggie? (REGGIE doesn’t answer ) Reggie? How did the talk go? REGGIE keeps walking. WILF watches him and then rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF walks in, goes to a costume and takes out a bottle o Whiskey from a pocket. From another pocket, he takes out plastic cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF walks over a bridge towards the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE, alone, staring out into the landscape, observing a deer. WILF’S VOICE (whispering) ‘Tis I. REGGIE half turns as WILF joins him.  47

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (admiring the deer) That’s a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I really can do without this at my time of life.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (pause) Do you want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) No. WILF produces the whiskey and two plastic cups.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (a ritual) Shall we? REGGIE observes, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN and CISSY are strolling. Now and then CISSY steals a glance at JEAN, monitoring her sadness.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Don't worry darling, I know where the boys are. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we sit for a moment? (gestures to a bench by the rose bed; they sit, she looks around) A few residents with visitors, among them OLLY slowly bouncing his GRANDDAUGHTER, DAISY, on his shoulders. JEAN CISSY catch the tail end of OLLY’S pony-ride. OLLY begins put her down.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No Grandpa! One more! OLLY struggles to put her back on his shoulders.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh, look, there's Olly with his grandchildren. (calling) Daisy, sweetheart! OLLY gently puts DAISY on the ground, who runs over and gives CISSY a big hug.  48

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which hand? CISSY has taken a sweet from her pocket and holds her han behind her back. DAISY chooses a hand and CISSY gives her treat. The parents of the child wave to CISSY and then be to DAISY, who runs back.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Bye-bye, Cissy - CISSY smiles and waves.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: How lovely it is to have visitors, like family. Will you have visitors, Jean? No response.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (trying to get out of her funk) At least the garden is a joy.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (eyes and attention on NOBBY, who is now walking nearby) Yes, and the woods are lovely too. You know Jean, for someone like me, who never married, never had children, whose nearest and dearest are long departed, this place is a God-send, a blessing, like a fairground ablaze with fairy lights - (lost for a moment; then) The bluebells were quite glorious this year. But they're finished now.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Like us.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: And you should have seen the polyanthus and forget-me-nots. I don't expect you get them in Karachi. JEAN flicks her a sideways glance, as CISSY puts a sweet mouth. She offers one to JEAN.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The yellow ones are my favourite.  49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and WILF are sitting inside holding plastic cups containing whiskey. They have been drinking for awhile. REGGIE is in the process of refilling his.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: So, come on, old son, break into song. REGGIE smiles. He’s been talking about aging.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: .--and in that way, we’re not the same. I’m not like you, Wilf. I positively liked getting old. Physical decay has seemed natural and inescapable. I think I can say I've welcomed the inevitable cheerfully. I’ve made the transition from opera star to old fart with aplomb (beat) Then Jean arrives...

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I remember thinking when you two got married...she was much more ambitious than you-

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course she was. She was more ambitious than all of us.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: -if I know anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What can you know about it?  50

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I was your best man, Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, and then you were married to the same woman for thirty thousand years. Call me old fashioned but did she know how often you were unfaithful to her?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: You say some very harsh things, Reg. (gets up, a little unsteady. ) I think I’1l have myself a widdle. (looks around for the right tree, a little tipsy) You're right, Reg. I hate growing old. Hate every bloody moment of it. If it's not your prostate, it's piles. And then it's peeing five times a night. If you’re lucky. WILF steps off the Summer House and stumbles to a nearby tree. He unzips and begins to pee when he catches a glimpse of CISSY and JEAN walking nearby and sees that they have spotted him. WILF (CONT’D) (shouts as he is peeing) You may want to avert your gaze, ladies. This may take a while. A wise man goes when he can, girls. A fool goes when he must. He looks up to see REGGIE still in the Summer House, standing at the edge, wanting to flee.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy, Reg, easy- By this time, CISSY and JEAN are near enough for JEAN to see REGGIE as he indelicately climbs down from the Summer House, takes a few steps, his back to them.  51

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (as they approach) Look! Here's Jean in all her glory.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I know. How are the mighty fallen.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (glances at REGGIE as he goes to kiss JEAN on both cheeks) Tactless as ever. You haven't changed a jot.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (admiring JEAN) Didn't I say so? Didn't I say she still looks like a young girl? JEAN takes a step towards REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Reggie, don’t I get a kiss? (he keeps his back to her) Reg? (takes a step closer) I apologise for hurting you. Please be kind to me. We were different people then. There. I've rehearsed saying that for the past week. Brief silence. He registers what she’s saying, looks away. He starts

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: He's upset because he wasn't warned that you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m not upset - to walk.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Reg. It’s the first time we've seen each other in God knows how many years.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Ninety-seven.  52

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Has it been as long as that? How time flies. (thinks a second) Oh, you’re joking.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What's wrong with Bobby? He nods towards the garden.

dialogues.speaker: TERRACE
dialogues.text: BOBBY, a little distance off, stands gesticulating. He taps his watch, makes imploring gestures, taps his watch again, beckons. Now, exasperated, he takes a few steps as if walking away, then returns, a little closer now, and starts gesticulating all over again. WILF’S VOICE I think he’s trying to tell us something. (calling) Bobby, give us a clue, for God's sake. Film, book or play?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Cissy! All their eyes on BOBBY.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It's for you, Cissy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (a shouted whisper) The note!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (calling) I couldn't read your handwriting!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Meeting! Now!

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (remembering) Oh yes, the emergency - She hurries off towards BOBBY.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I wonder what that’s all about.  53 JEAN looks round and doesn’t see REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Where’s Reg?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (looks down the path) There he is.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (starts down the path, calls out) Reg! Why does he treat me like this? It's not fair. As if I haven't suffered enough.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (calling out to her) NSP, Jean, NSP.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (turns her head) And what, for God's sake, does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s one of our rules. In fact, it’s our motto. NSP. No Self Pity. She turns and walks towards REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking towards the Church, carrying their instruments, a procession of the string quartet, BILL, lst violin, REGIN 2nd violin, FRED, viola, and LEO, cello. We can’t make ou the words, but there seems to be a disagreement between them. SIMON and ANGELIQUE carry music stands. JEAN making her way down the path, looking this way and that. The sound of the first movement, Allegro con spirit of Haydn’s 'Sunrise' Quartet begins as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music faintly behind her, JEAN pauses, peers about. A the end of the path, is a church. JEAN takes a few steps towards it, looks more closely and sees the door is ajar.  54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks inside, goes in, looking about. At the other en she sees REGGIE silhouetted behind a lattice screen.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Reggie? May I join you?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (vehement ) No, you may not.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I've walked miles to find you, Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Just leave me in peace, Jean -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I just want to - She starts to advance.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, just leave me in peace! Leave! Leave!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (shocked) Reggie!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I said leave! Emotional, about to leave, doesn’t. She sits at the edge a pew. From afar, the strains of the Haydn quartet. REGGIE finally walks over to her, stands a short distance away. After a long pause, he relents, and hands her a spotless white handkerchief. She dabs at her eyes and nos

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (smelling the handkerchief) Pino Silvestre. I didn't know you could still buy it. (dabs her nose, then aware of him gazing at her) What?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I can't ever remember you crying.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you’d become religious.  55

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I haven't. I was simply trying to avoid you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (handkerchief to her nose) My mother taught me never to let others see I was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Your mother knew all about hiding her feelings. It was easy for her. She didn't have any.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Don't be unkind about her.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I liked your father. When he heard that you'd left me, he telephoned and said, ‘Sorry, old chap, but count your blessings. I'm still married to her mother.’ REGGIE moves towards the door. Brief pause.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I apologise for hurting you. Please be kind to me. We were different people then. There. I've been rehearsing saying that for the past week.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (close to the door) You've said it before. You're repeating yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (thinks ) Oh God. (brief silence) Why do we have to grow old?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Because that’s what people do. A brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What I did was unforgiveable - but I was young and foolish. (he nods, moves closer to the door) Reggie, we have to come to some arrangement. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can't keep avoiding each other or, worse, bickering like children every time we meet -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (at door, interrupting) Jean, I don't want to talk about it. I don’t want to re-live ancient history. You're here. I'm here. Trapped. That's all there is to it. Silence but for the distant music.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? He broods for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: There’s always the cliché button. The one that says, 'Grin and bear it.'

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: How about trying the one that says ‘forgive and forget' - ? (REGGIE shakes his head; she again smells the handkerchief) The same cologne. The smell takes me back. (looks away) It takes me back to you, Reg - Though trying not to, REGGIE looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF walks into the greenhouse, is about to put the bottle and cups back into their hiding place. Stops and sees DR. COGAN between costumes, on the far side of the greenhouse, sitting and smoking. She turns. They look at each other. Overlap GEORGE and HARRY singing “Underneath the Arches.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gala committee, CEDRIC, BOBBY, ANNE LANGLEY and LETIT seated round the table as CISSY, flustered, enters. CEDRI puts a hand up to hold her off. GEORGE and HARRY doing Flanagan & Allen’s “Underneath the Arches” with DAVE on piano. RESIDENTS are seated at various places in the room GEORGE and HARRY continue until CEDRIC puts his hand up a and stops them from completing their song.  57

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: I’ve changed my mind. I don’t think it’s sophisticated enough for the gala.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We’ve been at it for a month.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What do you mean, it’s not sophisticated enough?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Exactly what I say. GEORGE and HARRY start to leave, GEORGE turns -—

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Cedric. I just want to be clear on one thing. You once said you sang the title roll in Julius Caesar at Covent Garden.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: We can’t find any record of it.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (flustered) I didn't say I sang Giulio CH- sare, I said I was considered for it. A giggle or two from eavesdropping residents seated in th music room.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Right. Well you’ve considered us and, unlike you, we’re singing it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re singing it. GEORGE and HARRY leave. NIGEL, baritone, belts out a brief phrase or two from Jul Caesar. The title role. He finishes.

dialogues.speaker: NIGEL
dialogues.text: Giulio CH-sare. Act 1, Scene 2. CEDRIC, trying to save face, looks at CISSY.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (looks sharply at CISSY) Yes, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: What happened?  58

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: We started a half-hour ago. You’re late.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Well, here I am. LETITIA raises her eyes to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to LETITIA) What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I thought she saw something. I was afraid we were leaking again.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Have you asked Reggie to sing La donna 6 mobile at the gala?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh God, I forgot!

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Good. Don't. For once, your forgetting, has paid dividends. I have a brilliant idea.  59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY enters a cooking class in progress - To Be Scripted

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table on the small terrace, a RESIDENT, (Real Name: CATHERINE WILSON) is surrounded by family with a lit cake softly singing “Happy Birthday.” She opens a present - it a young photo of her in her prime, surrounded by a frame the little girl has painted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESME at the piano, being taught by her Grandmother, LETIT Others in the room watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amateur Night at Beecham House. TWO YOUNG GIRLS on violin their parents watch and clap. Their performance is follow by ESME continuing Haydn’s “Military Minuet” embellished OLLY on clarinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LETITIA is sitting at the piano tinkling at “O Sole Mio.” CATHERINE WILSON begins to sing, mid-phrase. As she’s sin NIGEL joins in - his booming voice startling the other RESIDENTS. They continue the song together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE and HARRY singing “Are You Havin’ Any Fun?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE, at the piano, playing DeBussy’s “Girl with the Flax Hair.” ANGELIQUE, cleaning. RESIDENTS seated around the r listening. Among them, TONY, who takes his trumpet out of case, putting in a mute. He approaches the piano and begi to accompany DAVE. The classical song turns into a jazz r ANGELIQUE runs out of the COMMON ROOM - brings back with DR. COGAN. They greatly enjoy this special event.  60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE, reading Rilke’s “Letters to a Young Poet,”, looks and sees JEAN standing above him.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (smiles at REGGIE) Would you like to go for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the backs of REGGIE and JEAN sitting on a bench. They appear to be watching the string quartet rehearsing the Menuetto in patterns of sun and shadow. A summer idyll. Angle, from the front, JEAN is actually contemplating the answer to a question REGGIE has asked.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: -+.- No, I was only married twice after you and I annulled. First was Charles Tripper. Charles and I lasted four years, although we were rarely together. (MORE)
