dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was a business man who mixed business with pleasure one too many times. And then five years after that, I married Edward Fitzroy. He wanted me to retire and have children - so that was that. (beat) You never married ... again?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t want to anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: When I signed on to do Romeo and Juliet in 1972, I heard you backed out. Was that because of me?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And when I played Aida, did you renege on the role of Radames once I joined?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And then were you to play the Prince in Rusalka until you heard...

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why did you come here?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: My darling George died.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: George?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: My dog - all of a sudden I felt lonely. The STRING QUARTET stops playing and a spat develops betw them. JEAN and REGGIE watch, amused.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Would you say it’s time we resume our walk? They both rise.  62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and JEAN, walking.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: ..-but I had no choice but to come here. I have very little - the truth is - (hesitates) I have - financial problems. All I have now are my clothes and jewelry. (nothing from REGGIE) - and I didn’t confide in anyone because I just didn’t want any fuss. Quite frankly, I was embarrassed. You know what the media are like. They were always beastly to me and if they learned I'd ended up here, they'd gloat.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (a little acid) Really? I’m surprised the media still has any interest in you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, do piss off, Reggie, there’s a dear. As a matter of fact, and this will obviously surprise you more, I continue to cut a figure. The other night, I was Sir George's guest at Covent Garden. When I entered the box I received an ovation.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (zings her) And now you’re here - scary. JEAN gives REGGIE an elbow.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (they walk, zings back) What do you do when you’re not giving your little “talks?”

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: If I need to tire myself, I think about art. And if I need to exhaust myself, I think about life. But art - He suddenly breaks off, catching sight of someone through the trees. He turns vicious, hissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the trees, 63

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bitch! (JEAN is alarmed) See her? See her, there she goes, Angelique, see her? See her? (not shouting, but loud) Bitch, cow, sodding frog! oblivious, some distance off, wanders on through in and out of dappled light, towards the glade.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She won't give me marmalade at breakfast. She gives me apricot jam.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You hate apricot jam.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: But Wilf loves it, she does it deliberately. (a little louder) Bitch! Cow! Skinny-arse French twat! (without pause turns back to JEAN as if nothing has interrupted him) Art is my chief preoccupation, Jean, its meaning, its significance, its ability to educate and enthrall, to inspire and civilise. REGGIE takes a book from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (ironic) So you do a lot of reading.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes, I do a lot of reading. You might want to look at this. He turns to a page. She takes the book and begins to read

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: “Works of art are of an infinite loneliness and nothing can reach them so little as criticism. Only love can grasp them and keep hold of them and be just to them.” She looks up at him. Pauses, and shares with him somethin quite private -  64

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was after I had passed my peak - that the pressure became huge. And I was so aware of criticism and the importance of getting a good review...the next thing has to be as good or better and of course it can’t be, so in the end you get very nervous. They are closer than they have been since they met. Very close. Suddenly, they hear a noise. JEAN and REGGIE look around. Behind a hedge they see a startled ANGELIQUE and SIMON quickly gathering up a blanket. They both stand, SIMON holding the blanket under his arm. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: We weren’t doing anything.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) You weren’t asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the outside: FELICITY accompanying NIGEL doing “Tit- Willow.” After a few phrases, camera pans over to the SMA MUSIC ROOM. Seated are CEDRIC, CISSY and REGGIE. Though w hear, CEDRIC is talking to them while WILF closes the doo

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Where is this going, Cedric?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: I'll cut to the chase. I have a brilliant suggestion. Since the four of you are here together again, I put it to you, that you should perform - at - the - gala - (dramatic pauses) - the quartet from Rigoletto.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (gasps) | That’s amazing. I’ve been listening to us, Rig -

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) Think of the publicity, The Times, The Telegraph, Opera Today. We have four of the finest singers in English operatic history. We’d more than sell out.  65 Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (quietly to REGGIE) We all know the bloody thing, we won't have to rehearse that much.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: But Jean won’t sing in the gala.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Oh, but you must change her mind. She’s a huge draw. It would be as if Maria Callas were making a come- back.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I want to sing with Jean again.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (looks at others) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: They were married, but it didn’t -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: No- Cissy, leave it out. No, I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (studies REGGIE) Well, it’s a shame. I can’t count the number of galas you have graced over the years with your incomparable voice, and I mean that sincerely. I don’t think you realize it Reggie, but people still talk about your ‘Celeste Aida’ four years ago. Your ‘Ave Maria’ two years ago. (REGGIE beginning to weaken) I know you don’t think much of me, Reggie, that’s fine, but for what it’s worth, when I heard you sing your ‘Nessun Dorma’ at the gala last year, all I thought was ‘Eat your heart out, Pavarotti!’ (REGGIE weakening more) With this one concert, we could raise enough money to get us through and attract much needed new benefactors. You would help save Beecham House, Reginald. (meaningfully) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, art is a luxury to be paid for by those to whom it matters. Silence. CEDRIC senses the hook is set. CEDRIC (CONT’D) Well, I must leave. At any rate, I appreciate your consideration. CEDRIC leaves.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (trying to be off-hand) It’s one gala, Reg. You could do it. You could persuade Jean. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (looks at WILF, says wryly) Well, money has always driven art. He takes out his notebook and pen.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: One gala. It’s our life.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (as he’s writing) Count Kaiserling commissioned the Goldberg Variations. Culture wasn't spread by artists but by merchants - (hands the note to CISSY) It’s to save Beecham House.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Well done, Reg.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear, dear, Reggie.  67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN sits in fading light reading REGGIE’S book by Rilke. Suddenly, the door opens, CISSY darts in, puts the folded note on a table and disappears. Intrigued, JEAN rises, goes over to the door. She unfolds the note and reads. She is puzzled and suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. COGAN is seated at her desk, leaning back in her chair. WILF seated.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Just two favours - DR. COGAN wishes to bring the negotiation to a conclusion -

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Exactly what do you propose?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: “The Swan” restaurant. Just the four of us.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Four?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Me, Reggie, Cissy and Jean. Nobby will drive us.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with Tadek.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Night off. (she’s uncertain) If we can persuade Jean to sing at the benefit Gala, think of the money we'd raise. Cedric said we could charge Covent Garden prices.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (writing it down) In by ten-thirty. No later.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Twelve-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: No.  68

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What brand do you smoke, Lucy? She looks at him. Starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Twelve-thirty. No later.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Done, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: And please, call me Dr. Cogan.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Done. Dr. Cogan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Why is it, Wilfred, that I always have the impression you're up to no good?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Ah, that's because I'm always up to no good. (sees flowers in a vase) May I? And please call me Wilf. WILF takes one and puts it in his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: What’s the second favour?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I‘ll pick the lesser of two evils. You want to call me Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Yes, for starters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want those in my care to become too familiar.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Try it and see.  69

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Why do you persist in flirting with me?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Because you're a cracker, Lucy. Not a bird, not a girl, not a bimbo, but a rare species, a real woman.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (starts to rise) I'm flattered, but I have professional ethics to uphold.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Throw caution to the winds, Lucy. If we were to - how shall I put it? - make magnificent music together, I would never report you -

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: (ushering him to the door) That is reassuring, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (rising) Think about it, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: No, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: A weekend in London?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: No, Wilf. WILF, at the door, takes the hint.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: No one will know, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: But I will know, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (vague gestures of promise) Lucy, an older man - vintage wine - seasoned wood -

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Did you say seasoned wood? WILF smiles.  70 Overlap, from a MUSIC ROOM, a muted trumpet (TONY ROSE) practicing the quartet from Rigoletto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF and CISSY, dressed for the occasion but in clothes a little out of date. REGGIE, also very smart, on the look-out. All three are pleasurably excited.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Cissy, remember, as rehearsed, wait until she's legless, then we hit her with it.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (nods ) I won't say a word until you give me the cue.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: We'll get her so sozzled she'll say yes to anything -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (hissing) She's coming - Here she is. (resolve weakening) Oh God, I don't know why I agreed to this - JEAN emerges on the landing also smartly dressed for the evening.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to WILF, sotto voce) She looks - fairly all rightish. As JEAN walks to the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You look lovely, Jean -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: You give new meaning to the word ‘chic’. You agree, Reg? REGGIE forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. This is so - so very kind of you.  71

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: It’s the least we can do.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: The very least. JEAN, at the top of the stairs, pauses, looks down as REG reads her mind. He bounds up the stairs and offers his ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all get into the van - it leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS, 40's, Danish male, leads JEAN, REGGIE, WILF and CISSY through the dining area, crowded with patrons. The quartet seems out of place, dressed in the fashion of the 70's. As LARS leads them to their table.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: This way, Mr. Bond. We have your table ready and a bottle of the house red and a bottle of the house white, just as you asked.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lars. Quick as you can. The four walk out of shot to the booth. INT. THE SWAN —- DINING ROOM - NIGHT WILF, tipsy, finishes a bottle by topping up their glasses as they are about to finish their main courses. A WAITER puts more bottles on the table, takes the empty ones, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: A toast! To you, Jean. From all of us. Welcome. They clink glasses to JEAN - she looks at them warmly.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You have to make eye contact when you clink or else it’s bad luck.  72 They re-clink their glasses, making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Cheers! While they finish their main course:

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (staring at JEAN, a bit in her cups) Jean, do you listen to your old recordings? Before JEAN can answer.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I listen to us a lot. As a matter of fact, they wanted Reggie to sing La donna @ mobile for the Gala. But now, Jean, it's so exciting they want us — WILF puts a restraining hand on CISSY'S arm.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (jumping in) “La donna @ mobile qual plumo al vento.” Women are as fickle as a feather in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (she eats and drinks, ignoring the inference) I fell in love with you when I first heard you sing that.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (he sips wine) That’s why I never sang it again. I took twelve curtain calls.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You took nine, I took twelve.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Who’s counting? JEAN eyes him, eating and drinking. WILF refills her glass, but JEAN remains stone cold sober. The others do not.  73

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The other night, at the opera house, as Sir George's guest I received a standing ovation. Wasn't that something?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Now you're doing it again.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (rather tiddly) Repeating yourself. But what's it matter? In opera, we repeat ourselves all the time, repeat, repeat, repeat ourselves-— (WILF joins in) -ourselves, ourselves, (in Italian) - ci ripetiamo, ci ripetiamo, continuamente -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You’re both drunk. REGGIE nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Si, perché no. E Adesso... (A toast to the quartet in Italian) Un brindisi al quartetto Everyone raising their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (as they are toasting) What quartet?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Cheers!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Cedric wants us to sing at Verdi's Birthday Gala - (put his hand out to JEAN) - wait for it, wait for it - Pregnant pause. WILF nods to REGGIE. Then:

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (in Italian) - il quartetto dal Rigoletto.  74 They smile crookedly. Expressionless, JEAN looks shocked. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (tipsy) That means the quartet from Rigoletto.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (stunned) What a damn fool idea.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s a great honour, Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: A great honour?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: She said a great honour! She agreed! She’s legless!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No, I’m not legless. I haven’t agreed to anything. And don't talk about me as if I'm not here. (she looks at all of them) This is why you asked me to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: No, we asked you because - He breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: - because we love you. They avert her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something? When did you last sing? This morning in the bath? In the shower? Has anyone heard you recently? Have you any idea of the noise you now make? Do you really want to be a laughing stock? Why didn’t you have the guts to just tell me what you wanted? How shameful of you to try to trick me. You’re pathetic. JEAN rises and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Whoops.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Does that mean yes?  75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN marches from the pub. NOBBY exits the van and stands by the car door.

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: D'you have a good time?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, WILF, REGGIE and CISSY begin to walk unst through the restaurant. WILF tries to pick a flower from and ends up toppling the vase, spilling the water. led WILF (walking away) I think I spilled, WILF goes to leave, CISSY is ahead. They pass a televisio the bar. CISSY continues on but something catches WILF an REGGIE'S eyes and they stop: A RAP GROUP singing but ther of course, no sound. WILF (CONT’D) What d'you think they're singing, Reg? After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Il quartetto da Rigoletto. Angle from the back of WILF and REGGIE - we see WILF is gesturing, imitating the rap group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN stares through the van window as WILF and REGGIE sta to stagger out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (raps in an English accent) .-.and I’m gonna live to be a hundred, And I can tell you why, (measures up with his arm) ‘Cos I can still get it up - oh so high!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (gestures with his arm, but much lower) He can still get it up - but not so high. 1 eed (laughing) Yo, yo, oh so high.  76

dialogues.speaker: NOBBY
dialogues.text: (calling from the van) Sorry to interrupt Gents, but Miss Horton would like to go back. The van’s engine starts.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yo, yo, yo, not so high. WILF, REGGIE and CISSY stagger to the people carrier and get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN sits on the right side, staring out of the window. On the left side, REGGIE is staring out of his window, trying to stay awake. WILF and CISSY are asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 RPM record coming out of sleeve and onto a turntable. Close up of the needle hitting the record. JEAN is silhouetted, sitting, listening, following almost soundlessly to her aria from Madama Butterfly, “Un Bel Di Vedremo.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN enters the dining room in her dressing gown and walks up to the table.  77

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you just come out with it - instead of this charade of taking me to dinner. Why didn’t you just say, you wanted us, average age hundred and ninety-eight, singing the quarter from Rigoletto? An honour? It’s not an honour? It’s not an honour, it’s insanity. What you did was disgusting. All of you! (turning on REGGIE) I’m going to say something very rude to you - Fuck you, fuck you Reginald Paget. JEAN turns and walks out. As CISSY, REGGIE and WILF try to adjust, aware of people in the dining room staring. One of them looks out the window and sees paramedics wheeling a gurney carrying OLLY, with DR. COGAN following. She has words with the paramedics and then turns. She walks towards the dining room and enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I just want to say that it seems Olly isn’t well...it’s his recurring condition. But he will be checked and he’s going to be fine. People in the room look at each other. Focus on WILF, REGGIE and CISSY, who starts to put her earphones on. As DR. COGAN leaves we hear - HARRY’S VOICE Tell me, what are you doing in London?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: London? I’m here looking for work. HARRY’S VOICE Work?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Work. HARRY’S VOICE In London? Heh Heh.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why, isn’t there any work in London?  78

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Just a leetle bit!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just a leetle bit!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Just a leetle bit!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (posh) Hey Mister, with everything in life, I just would like to ask you one question.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (singing) Why you silly so-and-so. With all your dough. GEORGE and HARRY continue to sing Flanagan & Allen’s - “A You Havin’ Any Fun” with TONY ROSE on Trumpet and DAVE on piano. Through the window, we see -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY, NOBBY and SIMON picking flowers. CISSY walks away with a large bundle of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of JEAN’s face.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Go away! Go away! CISSY, standing in the open doorway, holding flowers.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: It's me, Jean. Cissy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I said go away! CISSY insists, holding the flowers. She comes a few steps in.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: But I’ve brought you a present, these are beautiful Iceberg roses.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Get out!  79

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Nobby has never allowed them to be picked before. (smiling, hopeful) You see, I just want to talk to you about the Quartet, it’s such a good - JEAN, out of her chair, grabs some of the flowers from CISSY.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Get out! Leave me alone you stupid cow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY, stunned, turns to run out the door as JEAN throws flowers at her. Covering her ears and eyes closed, she collides with a STAFF PERSON carrying a tray of glasses. She falls down near the railing. Alarmed faces from below look up. The remaining flowers float down to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimly lit room. Empty beds except for one that has screens partially concealing the patient. SHERYL, the nurse, in attendance. CIsSsy, in bed, subdued, but smiling bravely. REGGIE and WILF sit either side.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I don't know why everyone is making such a fuss. I'm sure she didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Jean always means it.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Does she? Oh, dear. It's so hard always trying to see the good in people. Maybe she’s just depressed.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you feel up to telling us what happened? SHERYL comes to her bedside and takes her pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy ) She threw something at me.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: What did she throw?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I think the heat is getting to her. I really do think she'll find it cooler in Simla. WILF, REGGIE and SHERYL exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: Very likely. DR. COGAN enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: I hope you haven't let them stay too long, Sheryl-

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: No, Dr. Cogan -

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (aside, to DR. COGAN) She'll be all right, will she?

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Just a little shocked, that's all. We'll keep her overnight.

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: You'll be fine in the morning won't you, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sheryl. (to WILF) Such a dear girl. Beautifully endowed, don't you think? WILF smiles. DR. COGAN gestures REGGIE and WILF to leave. She beckons SHERYL to the table near the door and looks at her notes.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (indicates an empty bed, quietly) I say, Lucy, I see you have an empty bed. You wouldn't like to keep me in overnight, would you? I feel a headache coming on.  81

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: She needs her sleep. Come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (as he’s leaving) It’s a shame to let it go to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and WILF walk down the corridor towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Remember Barber of Seville in the sixties at Covent Garden. Who was that big mezzo-soprano who was doing it with that little tenor in the bathtub. She got suctioned in. What was her name? (no answer from

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: In London, remember? The little guy couldn’t get her out. REGGIE still doesn’t answer, but smiles. They reach the top of the stairs. WILF (CONT’D) She was Italian. Remember? The tenor had to dial 999.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Beatrice Botticelli. At that moment they see JEAN'S head come into view slowly as she’s ascending the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (as she reaches the top of the stairs) How is she?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: She'll be fine. (She walks past them; they start down the stairs) You're right, Beatrice Botticelli. (slowly going out of view) They say her high notes were never the same.  82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERYL is at the foot of CISSY'S bed, reading notes. JEAN enters.

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss Horton, she's sleeping. JEAN hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Will you be sure she knows I came to see her?

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I‘1l come back in the morning. JEAN turns to go. From behind the screen:

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Jean? Is that you? JEAN is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SHERYL
dialogues.text: Mr. White.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (amazed) Frank White? May I see him?

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE SCREENS
dialogues.text: FRANK WHITE, a once dazzlingly handsome man, in his late 70's, and somewhat frail, lies in bed as JEAN comes round the screens.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I thought I recognised your voice. (a smile) As who could not? Just one of my spells. Nothing serious. But I won't be taking part in the gala. (he gazes fondly at her) You're still very lovely, Jean.  83

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I had no idea you were here. I would have visited you. (lovingly) Dear, dear Frank. (sits beside the bed) How are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you. (she takes his hand; they smile.) What a fling we had.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, what a fling, indeed. Short but giddy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And that luxurious hotel.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don't remember the hotel. I remember you rushing off and not seeing you for days on end.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, but you never guessed.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Never guessed what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You remember Enrico Cardinale?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The baritone? Of course I remember him. I had a fling with him, too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So did I. At the same time as I was having you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No! Did you, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I certainly did. (they laugh then look lovingly at each other) And you've been up to your usual tricks. (nods to CISSY in the other room) I heard it all from Cissy.  84

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don't know what came over me. I'm very ashamed but I'm so unhappy here and - Her voice trails off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Poor Cissy. She does so want to perform the quartet.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (studies her) A word of advice. Take part. If you can't sing at the gala, do conjuring tricks. The only alternative is to be the guest of honour at the crematorium. His words touch and trouble her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOBBY comes out of a store holding an umbrella and packag Wrapping paper is sticking out of one of the packages. Overlap Barber of Seville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOBBY continues past the Common Room. In the background, REGGIE, WILF, BOBBY and CISSY rehearsing BARBER OF SEVILLE. He continues to JEAN’S room and knocks. She answers, takes the packages, thanks him, gives him a note and some money. She says a few words to him that we don’t hear, as she closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, WILF and REGGIE are following a score. On TV is The Barber of Seville which they are, at times, watching. CISSY is sitting behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this, Wilfred?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: It’s the only trio we can think of, Bobby. The three of us did the Barber of Seville a dozen times.  85

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It’s your decision. Now, let’s see- (scanning the score) You'll each need at least six sessions - Panic:

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Six?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: We don’t have the time - They look up to see NOBBY come into the room. He hands th note to REGGIE as he whispers something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN is seated rather regally. WILF, REGGIE and CISSY are standing just inside the door, before her. They exchange silent looks.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Please sit. CISSY looks for a chair, vainly, and then sits on the edg of the bed. WILF, seeing no chair, up-ends a low wastepap bin and sits on it as REGGIE goes around the bed and sits in the chair by the dresser. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gestures) Wilf, you can sit on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I eat all my meals sitting on wastepaper-bins.  86

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (ignores his comment) First of all - again, I want to apologise to you, Cissy. What I did was appalling. And to you, Wilf.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I don’t remember you throwing anything at me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Please don’t make fun of me. And to you, Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I think it is I who should apologise to you, Jean. Their eyes meet. Finally she rises, goes to a side table, on top of which there are some poorly wrapped gifts.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I have gifts for you. She picks them up hands one to CISSY, one to WILF and wal around the bed and gives the third to REGGIE. She returns to her regal chair and sits.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Open them. CISSY tears open her package. WILF hold his badly wrapped gift out by one or two fingers.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: A CD of our Rigoletto! How lovely. WILF smiles ironically.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I know you already have copies, but I've signed those. So that makes them rather valuable. WILF resists a comment.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I also wrapped them myself.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I was thinking you did. JEAN ignores WILF, looks at REGGIE who has just opened hi gift, a jar of lime marmalade and looks up at JEAN. He is moved. Their eyes meet.  87 From somewhere, the sound of a violin playing Massenet’s Meditation from Thais, to the accompaniment of a harp. There is an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks at others) Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (confused) Yes. WILF rises awkwardly from his perch and moves to the door

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (at door) Thanks for the signed CD. Do you mind if we put them on eBay? Another awkward pause. WILF and REGGIE exchange shared lo CISSY, still seated on the bed, looks in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (rises) Thank you for coming. CISSY, rises, confused, takes out earphones attempts to untangle them.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: C’mon Cissy. CISSY goes toward WILF. REGGIE stands by his chair.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (still untangling earphones ) Have you changed your mind about the gala?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (emphatic) No.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (a slow burn) Of course you haven’t. Why should you? It’s only to celebrate and honour the birthday of one of the greatest composers for the human voice who has ever lived.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You must understand that I was somebody once -  88

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (still untangling) I thought I was somebody now -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: But to be honest, I shone the brightest in the firmament. WILF murmurs a Gaelic curse. JEAN realizes she’s gone too far.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cannot insult the memory of who I once was.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (explodes ) “The memory?” What do you mean “the memory?” Whose “memory?” Your fans? They’re dead. They’re all dead! Either that or they’re living here and soon will be. REGGIE holds a hand out to stop WILF.

dialogues.speaker: WILF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For Christ sake Jean, all you've ever done is to rely on external affirmation. And look what it cost you. Just fucking do it!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What you refuse to understand is that I’m a different person today.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. Nor are we. We've aged, that’s all. And it happened so fast, we didn’t have time to change. In spirit, I’m the same lovely lad I always was. I just happen to be trapped in a cage made of rusty iron bars, with, thank the lord, an undiminished level of testosterone.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I simply can’t. (all eyes on her; barely audible) My gift deserted me.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It deserted us, too, Jean. It’s called life.  89

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (looks at REGGIE) Yes. Shit happens.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh my darling, ageing is not for sissies.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. Her eyes fall on REGGIE’s. All smile.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Let go, Jean, let go. There’s no harm. Who knows - we might even enjoy it. We’re artists aren’t we? And we're meant to celebrate life. What else were we doing for all those years?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, Reggie. Are you telling me to go out and smell the roses?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh - the roses are long gone. But the chrysanthemums are extraordinary. It breaks the tension.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, Jean. If you say yes, Cedric will give us the star spot instead of Anne Langley.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (suddenly alert) Anne Langley? Here at Beecham house? I thought they’d committed her.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: She wanted to sing Violetta. She was a very fine Violetta.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh please, Cissy, Violetta is supposed to be dying of tuberculosis. Anne Langley looked as if she was singing Falstaff and she sounded like a cat hang gliding.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Well, she’s singing Tosca now. We would have the Finale, Jean!  90

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Tosca?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You were the most brilliant Tosca ever, Jean. The last time I heard her Tosca, her vibrato sounded like it was waving at us.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Not waving, but drowning.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Is that a yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chatter. CISSY and WILF at their table. Sudden silence, then excited murmurs. Entering the dining room, JEAN on REGGIE’S arm making a royal entrance. They pass ANNE LANGLEY. JEAN gives her a gracious smile, a Queen Motherly wave. ANNE LANGLEY stares back, she gets up and marches out of the dining room. JEAN and REGGIE reach the table.  91 As JEAN sits - One at a time, then joining all together, SIX RESIDENTS spread throughout the room start singing “Happy Birthday, EVA and MARTA bring a lit Birthday cake towards OCTAVIA i her wheel chair.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: (singing) Happy Birthday, dear Octavia. Happy Birthday to you. Applause from the room as JEAN watches. INT. ANNE LANGLEY’S ROOM - EVENING ANNE LANGLEY stands up, furious. On the wall, posters with her name written in large type. Photographs, one of her, curtseying low, being presented Queen.

dialogues.speaker: LETITIA
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together, Anne. What does it matter when you sing?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY
dialogues.text: I was told I had the finale. I've been second fiddle to Jean Horton for God knows how many years. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANNE LANGLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I only ever got the parts she turned down. In my sleep I'm a far better singer than she is and she’s - she’s so - so anorexic. Damn her! It’s not fair! She only sings from the chest. Damn her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear music from Rigoletto from inside the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STRING QUARTET, TONY ROSE, LETITIA with FELICITY turning pages, finish the music. Seated are REGGIE, WILF, CISSY and JEAN. All eyes on JEAN

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (quietly) I think we have to cut down the length. I don’t think I can get my breathing back. I’m not sure about the top notes. They nod. They knew her. They know her work ethic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intercut JEAN'S preparations with the Gala preparations. Played against BACH’s Piano Fugue in D-Minor. Concluding with - The Steinway being wheeled into place b NOBBY and SIMON, just below the stage while lights are be rigged. NOBBY then instructs SIMON upstairs on the railin how to use the follow spots.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRIVE, BEECHAM HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Cars arriving. Visitors of all ages tramp down towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VISITORS greeting RESIDENTS. Chatter, laughter. On an easel, a hand-painted poster: JEAN HORTON SINGS and other names. SHERYL and DWAYNE sit at a table issuing tickets and taking money.  93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESIDENTS being made up by DWAYNE, ANGELIQUE, MARTA, TRACY, and SHERYL. Chatter and excitement, occasional laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience continues to settle in. DR. COGAN greets some of the visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and WILF are putting the final touches to their Brindisi attire: hair, makeup, etc. behind the screens.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: ...and then I’1ll say that the quartet from Rigoletto is not only one of Verdi's masterpieces, but also one of the great milestones in the history of opera. And then I shall introduce each of us in turn -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (sitting at a mirror in her dressing gown, doing makeup and hair, etc.) I will enter last. WILF raises his eyes to heaven. CIssy, dressed for the Brindisi and holding articles of makeup is on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cissy, where are you going? You have to help me with my gown.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Of course I will Jean. I’m just going to do Anne Langley’s makeup.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You'll need a lot of makeup for that face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RESIDENTS, including CISSY, REGGIE and WILF, filing on to the stage and taking their places. BOBBY supervising. CEDRIC peers into the crowd from behind the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (to BOBBY) ...and that’s the critic from The Times.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE CURTAINS
dialogues.text: DR. COGAN goes to the front and faces the audience.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen- (a hush) Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Beecham House and our annual Gala in honour of Giuseppe Verdi. And today, we celebrate his hundredth birthday. First, I would like to express our debt of gratitude to the amazing Mr. Cedric Livingstone for organising the event. Applause. CEDRIC makes his entrance to his seat and acknowledges the applause graciously.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE CURTAINS
dialogues.text: BOBBY, in white tie and tails, peeping through the curtai at the audience.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, ladies and entlemen. And let me just say, in all modesty, great artists need a great director - Applause. CEDRIC milks it, and then sits.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN
dialogues.text: This year, in aid of our rebuilding programme, you have all responded so generously and we thank you for that with all our hearts. And, I, too, would like to thank all those taking part in the Gala itself. The preparations and rehearsals have kept everyone busy and excited for the past few months.  97

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I, and all my staff, feel highly privileged to have in our care such talented people, gifted musicians who seem to find renewed energy when they anticipate performing before an audience. It keeps them young.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE CURTAINS
dialogues.text: Sympathetic laughter and applause.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And just let me say something else on behalf of everyone working in Beecham House. We owe those in our charge an enormous debt. They inspire us. Yes, their love of life is infectious and gives us all faith in the future. I mean that. Now. I know many of you are eagerly awaiting our star turn this evening who has proved such an attraction but about whom I will say no more. Applause and murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you and I hope you have - I’m sure you will have an enjoyable afternoon. She takes her seat as LETITIA and FELICITY enter. CEDRIC ostentatiously starts the applause. LETITIA sits at the piano, FELICITY beside her to turn the pages. The audience begin to settle.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE CURTAINS
dialogues.text: BOBBY, in the wings through the curtains, turns, makes a gesture for the RESIDENTS (including REGGIE, WILF and CISSY) to be still, then a nod.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE CURTAINS
dialogues.text: 98 The lights dim. Murmur of anticipation. After a moment the curtains open and the RESIDENTS are revealed, made- up and glowing. Wild applause. BOBBY holds up his hands. Silence. BOBBY gives LETITIA the cue and she starts the introduction to the Brindisi. The residents begin to sing with great enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN, sitting at her mirror. The sound of applause. CISSY bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s so exciting. They loved the Brindisi.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You’ve kept me waiting. Please help me with my dress.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Instantly. REGGIE and WILF pop in on the way to their room —

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Who’s on next?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Anne Langley.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (alert) I‘’1l be right back. We hear ANNE LANGLEY begin her aria. JEAN leaves. REGGIE WILF share a look.  99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE LANGLEY is singing the aria from Tosca - Vissi D’Arte, accompanied by LETITIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peeking between the curtains backstage, JEAN watches and listens to ANNE LANGLEY’S every move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ANNE LANGLEY comes to the end of her Vissi D’Arte aria She sings astonishingly. JEAN stays to observes the appla as Gilbert and Sullivan wait in the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience applaud and cheer ANNE LANGLEY. She beams wi pleasure. Someone throws a corsage on to the stage. As sh starts to retrieve it, SIMON runs from the wings and hand to her. Gilbert and Sullivan come onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In full swing, LOTTE, NORMA and MARION perform the last chorus of Three Little Maids from School. They wear makeshift kimonos and flutter their fans expertly. The audience are enchanted and applaud wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CISSY is helping JEAN on with her costume.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Jean, I have a confession to make. I think I ought to tell you I hada one-night stand with Roberto D’Angelo, the same week you did.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (amused and surprised) Not you, too, Cissy? What a busy boy he must have been.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Yes and very potent. They smile at each other. CISSY is doing up the hooks on back of JEAN’S dress. After a moment -

dialogues.speaker: CISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long were you married to Reggie?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Not for very long.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Exactly nine hours. CISSY finishes JEAN’S hooks and starts to put on her own dress.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Nine hours. How long did you know each other?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Before we were married, we had been, how shall I put it, passionate, if you know what I mean?  102

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Oh, I do, I do.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: After about a year, he got down on his knees and asked me to marry him. He was very old-fashioned, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: He still is.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he is. So I agreed and a date was fixed. But then we had to change it because I got a job at La Scala. And there I met- I met - She hesitates. Gilbert and Sullivan enter the Common Room, exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Go on, go on, I’m breathless, who was it?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No names, no arias. It was nothing serious- just- just one night - with an Italian tenor.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Just one night?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Two. They never take no for an answer. Anyway, Reggie and I were eventually married at three o’clock on a Sunday afternoon in May. My father gave us a suite at the Savoy Hotel. We were to spend the night there and then go to Paris the next morning for our honeymoon. We had a champagne supper. Scrambled eggs, toast and lime marmalade. And then I blurted it out. I told him I'd been unfaithful when I sang at La Scala.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (shocked) You didn’t!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Why? Why did you tell him?  103

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just did. I felt the need to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: That’s always a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Reggie demanded to know why I didn’t cancel the wedding. He was very angry... She breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: And he walked out.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No, he ran.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: But he was heartbroken, Jean, by your confession, because you'd been unfaithful - After a moment, JEAN nods, wearily, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I know that now. I was young and impetuous and driven. (beat - lost in thought) I was afraid of us. I had my career.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: That’s why you cheated?  104

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. That's why I told him. (beat) And that was the mistake of my life. And now it’s too late.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: You still have your future.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think there’s a lot of it - there just isn’t. It’s all been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE, HARRY, TONY and DAVE finish “Underneath the Arches” to great applause. They bow, look at CEDRIC who is not applauding. They wave their hands to encourage him to clap. He does so. Limply.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Encore! Encore!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought you’d never ask - CEDRIC gives them a vulgar V sign as they go into ‘RUN RABBIT RUN’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEAN is now doing up the hooks on CISSY’S dress. JEAN struggles with CISSY’S hooks.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: God, this is too tight for you, Cissy, I can’t fasten it-

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (becomes agitated) But I altered it, I altered it- A knock on the door and SIMON puts his head round.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: It’s getting near, ladies - (calling) Did you hear that, gents, it’s getting near?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Simon. SIMON goes. JEAN still struggling. CISSY, more agitated.  105

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I altered it. Try, Jean, do try-

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I am trying, I can’t fasten it-

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Stop, stop! I’1l take it off, I‘ll let it out a bit more. (takes off her costume) Where’s the scissors? She starts wandering aimlessly.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Cissy, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Home. Didn't I tell you? I’m going home -— CISSY’S eyes have a vacant look.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? CISSY starts to leave the dressing area and heads into the COMMON ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m off. Goodbye. JEAN hobbles after her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (calls out) Crisis! WILF and REGGIE, in various stages of formal dress, follow CISSY and JEAN. CISSY sees them.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Oh! How awful, I nearly went without saying goodbye. Goodbye, Wilfred, Reginald. Wish me bon voyage. CISSY starts to hurriedly walk through the COMMON ROOM toward the French doors.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: For God’s sake, don’t let them see her in this state - REGGIE moves fast after her.  106

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the sound of the string quartet playing the Adagio, RE chases after CISSY. GEORGE and HARRY watch bewildered as head back to the dressing area. CISSY makes for the French doors as REGGIE reaches her, panting.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Cissy, you’re not to leave. It's Verdi’s birthday gala. Now. (CISSY stares at him) We're doing the Quartet from Rigoletto. The Quartet, Cissy-

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: I do hope it goes well. Goodbye- (suddenly stops, looks past REGGIE) Isn’t that Jean Horton? I thought she wouldn't sing anymore- REGGIE turns to see JEAN and WILF approaching.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: She’s done for.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (with some severity) Cissy, pull yourself together. CISSY stares blankly at her; JEAN grips her hands.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Mother and father are waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You're not going anywhere, you’re staying here, with your fellow artists. With your friends, Cissy.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Friends who love you, Cissy. We love you, Cissy! (nothing from CISSY) What's the Hindi for love? (loudly) I adore you, Cissy. Don’t run out on me.  107

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Cissy, your ship doesn’t sail for two weeks. A faint, flickering response from CISSY.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t it? (suddenly alarmed) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Late. You have work to do on your dress. An uneasy pause. Then, in a rush:

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes. (WILF takes her by the hand, starts to lead her back) It's always the little things that upset one, it’ll fit, I know it'll fit- REGGIE gives JEAN his arm as they, too, start to go back.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (a sigh of relief) That was a close run thing. Well done, Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I had a great deal of experience with my mother. Only she used to become violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quartet is coming to the end of the third movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the dressing area CISSY wriggles into her costume.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Let’s try again- JEAN starts to do her up. WILF is in the midst of stuffing a second pair of socks into the front of his pants.  108

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (to the girls) How’s that? Am I a fine figure of a man or am I not? REGGIE’S VOICE I have to say I find it very distasteful. The girls ignore WILF.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: (to JEAN) Well? JEAN manages to fasten the dress.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Just.

dialogues.speaker: CISSY
dialogues.text: Thank God for that.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Well? With one finger from each hand pointing in the direction his crotch. WILF (CONT’D) Well? No_one answers. As they continue getting. ready WILF walks back into his dressing area, removing the socks, shaking his head. WILF (CONT’D) It was just a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The string quartet finish the third movement. JOEY, seate near CEDRIC, starts to applaud. CEDRIC instinctively grab JOEY'S arm to stop him. JOEY aggressively whips his hand away. The string quartet begins the last movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE is looking at his score when SIMON pokes his head around the screen.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Places, ladies. (a little louder) Places, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Simon. REGGIE gets up, taking CISSY with him. They walk toward t backstage area.  109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The string quartet continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILF and JEAN walking toward the backstage area with their canes.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Jean, our sticks. I think we should try to get through without them.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can. My hip’s very bad tonight.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can either. But I think we should try. It would be more dignified. More operatic.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I may have to lean on you.

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: Lean on Reg, it’d be safer. And he’d be very pleased. He adores you. (she looks doubtful) Trust me. They enter backstage.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Does he?

dialogues.speaker: WILF
dialogues.text: (whispering) Of course he does. I don’t think Reg has ever stopped loving you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: How do you know? Has he said so? JEAN catches REGGIE’S eye. The String Quartet is coming to the end of the movement. JEAN holds and then comes to him. They look at each other for a moment, then he looks away.  110

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (meaningfully) At least you won't be singing at La Scala again.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. Never again. Never again, Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Is that an apology?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It is. (she looks at him) You look very handsome tonight, Reg.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (turning back to her) And you look very beautiful, Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And now we are old. A long look at JEAN from REGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (is it tongue in cheek?) Then let’s get married. The string quartet has just finished their last movement and the audience is applauding. After a moment, REGGIE Marches on the stage to an even bigger applause. INT. MAIN HALL —- DAY A BRIGHT SPOTLIGHT bursts onto REGGIE. The audience continues applauding, cheering and whistling. Some of the residents now stand or sit at the back and join in enthusiastically. REGGIE bows, puts on his reading glasses and produces pieces of paper.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, this afternoon, my three colleagues and I are hoping to transport you to times past. We have come to the conclusion, after much argument and discussion, that we are unchanged. At least in spirit. And that spirit is most intensely expressed when we sing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so, on this 10th of October, the anniversary of Guiseppe Verdi, I hope you will be moved by the glorious music. Rigoletto is one of Verdi's masterpieces. And the quartet is one of the great milestones in the history of opera. So now it is time for me to make the introductions. I myself am, of course, the Duke of Mantua, and as Rigoletto, we are fortunate to have the popular, celebrated baritone, Mr. Wilfred Bond. WILFRED walks on without cane to great applause and bows. When he straightens up:

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, as Maddalena, our own, our very own, the delicious Miss Cecily Robson. CISSY enters and curtsies to great applause and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And last, but not least, one of the great stars in the operatic firmament for whom, I know, you have all been waiting, please welcome as Gilda, the great, the incomparable, Miss Jean Horton. JEAN enters, without cane, walking with difficulty, can barely curtsey to the great applause and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the quartet from Act Three, Scene One of Rigoletto by the great maestro, Guiseppe Verdi. By now, the instrumentalists have assembled themselves next to the Piano. They begin to play the Quartet from Rigoletto. The singers will commence singing. During it, we will see JEAN faltering. She will lose her balance and start to sink as REGGIE puts his arm around her waist to steady her. JEAN will pick up again and the orchestra will continue. Various moments like this will occur until the quartet finishes. At the conclusion, the audience will applaud and the quartet take their curtain calls. During the applause, JEAN will whisper to REGGIE -  112

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: If you ever ask me to do this again, I‘1l kill you. They smile at each other as the audience continues to app
